race.name: Albia Holy Cow
race.tagline: Mormon Trail history and cattle encounters on Monroe County's pastoral Iowa gravel.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Albia Holy Cow is a local event in Iowa‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Iowa countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Trans Iowa, Spotted Horse Ultra.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Albia has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Albia has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Iowa rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Monroe County Fairgrounds venue provides RV camping sites with 200-rider cap and July 5th online registration deadline showing solid planning. Albia Chamber of Commerce partnership delivers local support with promises to 'show you around downtown and their picturesque square.'

length.explanation: Trevor Irwin podiumed the 50km in 1:58:09, noting the distance was 'right in his wheelhouse' for triathletes trying gravel. Another rider set 'a personal goal to complete the race in 4:30' on the longer distance but 'came in just late of the goal.' Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course founder discovered 'a number of Class B roads' with 'river crossings' and cattle encounters through moderate terrain. Officially classified as 'rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs' - countryside exploration without technical skill demands. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Course founder describes 'a fairly hill route, but there are a lot of long descents and nice flats to help you recharge and get ready for the next Class B challenge.' 2,500 feet over 60 miles with recovery opportunities. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 85¬∞F and lows of 68¬∞F, with a 48% chance of rain on any given day. Mid-July in Iowa delivers heat, humidity, and potential thunderstorms. Classic midwest summer conditions create endurance challenges without altitude or desert extremes affecting Monroe County fairgrounds start. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Iowa farmland through Monroe County stays near sea level. Altitude isn't a factor for Class B road challenges through cattle country and Historic Mormon Trail segments. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course founder encountered unexpected 'acres of grass-fed cattle, beautiful views' and 'a short ride along the Historic Mormon Trail' through Monroe County exploration. Pleasant countryside discovery without wilderness edge.

prestige.explanation: Regional Iowa Gravel Series race where Trevor Irwin podiumed 'as a triathlete trying gravel' demonstrates accessible competition level. 200-rider cap and fairgrounds venue show grassroots focus over elite field attraction.

race_quality.explanation: $40 entry gets 'chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations' while fairgrounds venue move shows organizational learning. Iowa Gravel Series framework covers basics competently without premium polish.

experience.explanation: Course founder called Monroe County exploration 'spectacular' after discovering unexpected cattle encounters. Albia Chamber encourages riders to 'plan to stick around after this adventure' for downtown exploration beyond racing.

community.explanation: Albia Chamber actively promotes post-race downtown exploration while Monroe County Fairgrounds RV camping creates gathering space. Iowa Gravel Series builds season-long community with $399 series pass connecting regional riders across 7 races.

field_depth.explanation: Performance spread from Trevor Irwin's competitive 1:58:09 podium to riders missing 4:30 completion goals demonstrates wide participation range. 200-rider cap shows recreational focus over competitive depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $40 grassroots entry includes 'chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations' with $60 adding lunch and shirt. $399 series pass for all 7 Iowa races delivers strong economics for circuit riders.

expenses.explanation: Monroe County Fairgrounds RV camping keeps lodging affordable in rural Iowa. $40-60 entry fees and regional driving accessibility create midwest racing economics without premium destination costs. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Albia Holy Cow gravel race Albia

videos.title: 2023 Holy Cow 100k Gravel Race - Albia, Iowa
videos.description: The 3rd race in the Iowa Gravel Series takes us to Albia, Iowa for the Holy Cow. This 100 kilometer race is chock full of gorgeous scenery, challenging climbs, treacherous b-roads and assorted wildlife (did anyone else spot a donkey?)

videos.title: How I Survived The Albia Holy Cow! Iowagravelseries
videos.description:
FROM THE RACE SERIES
[When I first rode West out of Albia, I didn‚Äôt know what to expect. I knew there were a number of Class B roads I wanted to travel along the way, but I didn‚Äôt expect to meet acres of grass-fed cattle, beautiful views, river crossings, and even a short ride along the Historic Mormon Trail. It was spectacular and the opportunity to explore Monroe county left me thinking, ‚ÄúHoly Cow this is cool!‚Äù

Albia is a fairly hill route, but there are a lot of long descents and nice flats to help you recharge and get ready for the next Class B challenge. The start location at the Monroe County Fairgrounds has plenty of RV camping sites available!]

Pease check out our sponsor; with a 15% coupon for your recovery needs.
https://realandnutrition.com/discount/mspodcast
https://o-liv.com
** gravel10 for a 10 percent discount on all o-liv.com website



Also, if you're not subscribed, please whack that button as it makes a difference for this channel. Thank you!

If you would like to buy me a coffee, here's my link
https://www.buymeacoffee.com/iowagravelgang?6qwptyyrboztqw6akt364ensim=j77qy222gbf5cmayq2ybib5z5q
Thank you all for your continued support!

videos.title: Cirrem 2022
videos.description:
A short film about the CIRREM gravel bike race. 

After a hard cold winter, the last weekend in February has become a pilgramize to the Cumming Tap in Cummings Iowa. It doesn't matter if it's sunny, raining, snowing or if the roads are mud or ice coated this the the first bike race of the season.

quotes.text: One of the key features of the route are the B roads - roads not maintained by the county. Depending on conditions these roads can either lead to Adventure or disaster.

I ran out of skill trying to go into a corner a little bit too fast and just didn't quite have the technique, so I was like I'm either falling down in the road or I'm going into the weeds - weeds are the way I thought I chose right.

key_challenges.name: Aggressive hills
key_challenges.description: Riders describe the hills as hard and aggressive, representing a significant challenge throughout the course.

terrain_notes.text: Roads are described as great quality despite challenging conditions. No ice reported, with roads staying in good condition.

race_day_tips.text: Plan for survival strategy - riders mention goal of getting to 30 miles and not dying, then making it back to the finish.
Be prepared for weather changes throughout the day - expect it to warm up as the day progresses.
Wind will be a challenge on race day - plan pacing and positioning accordingly.

additional_quotes.text: We've taken a little bit of a B-road off of the 50K completely. The 100K, you've got a little tiny section. We'll be able to hike a bike it.

rider_intel.search_text: Albia Holy Cow is a 60-mile gravel race in Iowa featuring aggressive hills that riders describe as hard and challenging. The course maintains good road quality with no ice conditions reported. Weather plays a significant role, with wind being a major challenge and temperatures expected to warm throughout the day. Riders adopt survival strategies, aiming to reach the 30-mile mark before focusing on the return. The race offers multiple distance options including 50K and 100K variants, with some course modifications made for wet conditions including B-road alternatives and potential hike-a-bike sections. The event attracts spectators who come to support friends and enjoy the race atmosphere in the scenic Iowa countryside.

photos.alt: Three cyclists in matching Omaha Velo jerseys pose on rural gravel road with corn fields in background - Albia Holy Cow - Albia, Iowa
First-person perspective of gravel cyclists riding on dirt road through rural farmland with GPS device visible on handlebars - Albia Holy Cow - Albia, Iowa
Post-race interview with cyclist wearing helmet and race director Chris McQueen in park setting with trees - Albia Holy Cow - Albia, Iowa
Course preview from Albia Holy Cow race footage
